t: Job 31
I*p made a covenant with mine eyes; why then should I think upon a maid?
For*p what portion of God is there from above? and what inheritance of the Almighty from on high?
Is*p not destruction to the wicked? and a strange punishment to the workers of iniquity?
Doth*p not he see my ways, and count all my steps?
If*p I have walked with vanity, or if my foot hath hasted to deceit;
Let*p me be weighed in an even balance, that God may know mine integrity.
If*p my step hath turned out of the way, and mine heart walked after mine eyes, and if any blot hath cleaved to mine hands;
Then*p let me sow, and let another eat; yea, let my offspring be rooted out.
If*p mine heart have been deceived by a woman, or if I have laid wait at my neighbour's door;
Then*p let my wife grind unto another, and let others bow down upon her.
For*p this is an heinous crime; yea, it is an iniquity to be punished by the judges.
For*p it is a fire that consumeth to destruction, and would root out all mine increase.
If*p I did despise the cause of my manservant or of my maidservant, when they contended with me;
What*p then shall I do when God riseth up? and when he visiteth, what shall I answer him?
Did*p not he that made me in the womb make him? and did not one fashion us in the womb?
If*p I have withheld the poor from their desire, or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail;
Or*p have eaten my morsel myself alone, and the fatherless hath not eaten thereof;
(For*p from my youth he was brought up with me, as with a father, and I have guided her from my mother's womb;)
If*p I have seen any perish for want of clothing, or any poor without covering;
If*p his loins have not blessed me, and if he were not warmed with the fleece of my sheep;
If*p I have lifted up my hand against the fatherless, when I saw my help in the gate:
Then*p let mine arm fall from my shoulder blade, and mine arm be broken from the bone.
For*p destruction from God was a terror to me, and by reason of his highness I could not endure.
If*p I have made gold my hope, or have said to the fine gold, Thou art my confidence;
If*p I rejoiced because my wealth was great, and because mine hand had gotten much;
If*p I beheld the sun when it shined, or the moon walking in brightness;
And*p my heart hath been secretly enticed, or my mouth hath kissed my hand:
This*p also were an iniquity to be punished by the judge: for I should have denied the God that is above.
If*p I rejoiced at the destruction of him that hated me, or lifted up myself when evil found him:
Neither*p have I suffered my mouth to sin by wishing a curse to his soul.
If*p the men of my tabernacle said not, Oh that we had of his flesh! we cannot be satisfied.
The*p stranger did not lodge in the street: but I opened my doors to the traveller.
If*p I covered my transgressions as Adam, by hiding mine iniquity in my bosom:
Did*p I fear a great multitude, or did the contempt of families terrify me, that I kept silence, and went not out of the door?
Oh*p that one would hear me! behold, my desire is, that the Almighty would answer me, and that mine adversary had written a book.
Surely*p I would take it upon my shoulder, and bind it as a crown to me.
I*p would declare unto him the number of my steps; as a prince would I go near unto him.
If*p my land cry against me, or that the furrows likewise thereof complain;
If*p I have eaten the fruits thereof without money, or have caused the owners thereof to lose their life:
Let*p thistles grow instead of wheat, and cockle instead of barley. The words of Job are ended.
